isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - CHASSIS ACCESSORIES - OPERATION - Hydraulic Brake System

svcproc.title: Hydraulic Brake System
svcproc.para: The Hydro-Max II hydraulic brake system uses hydraulic pressure from the power steering pump. If the flow is inadequate or interrupted, the monitor module is fed a signal from the flow switch, causing the monitor to turn on a brake warning light and start the hydraulic reserve pump to provide additional brake power. The reserve pump and brake warning light are also activated when the differential pressure switch (301) is tripped due to a pressure loss in one half of the brake system.

When key switch (24) is in the ignition or start position, power is supplied to circuit 13, fuse F3, circuit 90U, connector (47) and blocking diode assembly (48). From blocking diode assembly (48), power is supplied to circuit 90H, connector (2), circuit 90H, hydraulic brake relay (300) and to circuit 90F and the brake monitor module (49). The brake monitor module (49) is grounded through circuit 90-G/11-G/11-GL to cab ground stud (2G).

Battery power is applied to fusible link 90-FL, circuits 90, 90A and hydraulic brake relay (300). Power is also supplied from 90-FL to circuit 90/90B, conn. (2), fuse F33, circuit 90C, and hydraulic brake switch (50).

When the key switch (24) is moved to the start or ignition position, the flow switch contacts will be closed (engine is not running) and a ground path is provided from the switch over circuit 90L and 90K to a splice. From the splice, a ground path is provided over circuit 90M, connector (2), and circuit 90M to the brake monitor module alarm input (49-A). This causes the module to switch the alarm output (49-C) to ground which activates the alarm and warning light. From the splice, a ground circuit is also provided by way of circuit 90J to the hydraulic brake relay (300), causing it to energize. With the relay energized, power flows through its N.C. contacts, and circuit 90N to the reserve pump motor. This causes the reserve pump motor, which is grounded through its case, to run and provide additional brake power (fluid flow).

A signal path, circuit 90P, connector (2) and circuit 90P to brake monitor module connector (49-F) provides information to the module. The module continuously monitors the continuity of the reserve pump motor and power supplied to it, and activates the alarm and warning light under the following conditions:

item.para: If the pump motor winding opens up.
If the hydraulic brake relay (300) remains closed (provides power to circuit 90N and the reserve pump motor) after the engine is running, and the flow switch opens up.
If no power is supplied to the pump motor when the flow switch or differential pressure switch contacts are closed.

svcproc.para: When the brake monitor module switches its alarm output (49-C) to ground, the brake warning light illuminates by power flowing to the lamp feed connector (28) through the light, connector (26), and circuit 90T to the module at connector (49-C).
The alarm also sounds by power flowing to the B+ terminal of the alarm, through the alarm, and circuit 90S to the module at connector (49-C).

If ignition key is in the off position and the truck brakes are applied, the contacts of hydraulic brake switch (50) close. With the contacts closed, power flows through circuit 90D, connector (47), blocking diode assembly (48), connector (47) and circuit 90F to feed the brake monitor module at connector (49-E). At the same time a power signal is fed from switch (50) to circuit 90D, 90E, and the brake monitor module (49-G). This signal is compared to a signal provided from stop light switch (51) and circuit 70C/90R to the brake monitor module (49-H). If there is a voltage on just one of the two circuits 90E or 90R for longer than 14 ± 5 seconds, the warning light and alarm will be turned on.

When the brakes are applied, the hydraulic brake switch (50) also applies voltage to circuit 97M, connector (3) and circuit 97M to the ECM. At the same time, the stop light switch (51) applies voltage to the ECM through circuit 70C/97N, connector (3) and circuit 97N as a redundant signal. This signals the ECM that the brakes are applied.
